doc.title: EM Equity Strategy
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/EM Equity Strategy South Africa Macro Inflection Not Yet Priced Domestic Rotation to Drive Further Equity GainsEM Equity_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: South Africa's recent macro performance has been characterized by weak growth and rising debt. In contrast to the mainstream view, we see the growth shortfall as largely cyclical, held back by headwinds such as restrictive monetary policy. As these headwinds fade and as supply constraints also ease (e.g., in energy and logistics), we forecast that growth will accelerate from \(1.0\%\) in 2025 to \(1.6\%\) in 2026, reaching about \(2.5\%\) in the medium term. If combined with fiscal consolidation, this potentially supports a case for sovereign credit rating upgrades - a positive inflection point that we think is not yet priced into South African assets. Equities have performed well (MXZA is up nearly \(30\%\) ytd), but the rally has been narrow, led by Commodity Exporters, while the domestic pockets have been mostly flat ytd. A growth rebound could catalyze a rotation from selective exporters into Domestic Cyclicals.

Two major policy shifts are underway: 1) the SARB has reduced its effective inflation target from \(4.5\%\) to \(3\%\) , and 2) the fiscal authorities project rising primary surpluses that should stabilize debt this year. Market pricing does not fully reflect this: the local yield curve partly embeds sustained disinflation, and the market remains sceptical of a lower policy- rate path, while consensus expectations of ongoing fiscal slippage keep the curve steep and real yields elevated. Our inflation and rate views are dovish (aligned with the SARB's projections) and we view the fiscal plan as credible - supporting a bull- flattening of the yield curve and higher local equities via a lower equity risk premium and the market's high sensitivity to rates. Sector- wise, Banks and Retailers have outperformed Defensives and Exporters in past periods of declining rates. Moreover, South African Banks' profitability and ROEs have historically lagged their EM peers, alongside a weaker fiscal track record; a firmer fiscal trajectory and growth upturn could lift Bank ROEs, support higher valuations, and help sustain dividend payouts over time.

We upgrade South African equities: We raise South African equities to Overweight within our EM allocations, and expect further equity gains towards our refreshed 12- month target of 106,000 for the Top40 (JSE 40 index), which

Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
implies \(12\%\) local upside and \(17\%\) USD returns, driven by mid- teen earnings growth next year.

MXZA vs. CEE- 3 outperformance: Within the CEEMEA region, we see leadership rotating from the ytd winners (CEE- 3) towards South Africa, catalyzed by stretched positioning in CEE- 3 equities and concerns over taxes hikes for Polish Banks. We think MXZA vs. MXME offers an attractive entry point, with around \(20\%\) upside to 4Q24 relative highs.

Domestic rotation: Domestics have lagged Exporters by nearly 60pp ytd, with the relative performance near two- year lows and supportive relative valuations. The cyclical recovery that we expect and domestic equities' high sensitivity to lower rates will likely trigger a rotation into Domestic sectors.

Rate beneficiaries: Stocks that exhibit the highest correlations with 5- year local rates have traded in line with interest rate trends (inversely) in recent years. Since the SARB outlined its lower inflation target in May, these names are up about \(5\%\) on average and could see further upside as rates decline.

Intra- sector ideas: Within Exporters, the rally in gold miners has been backed by underlying earnings accrual and could extend given our commodities strategists' positive outlook for gold prices. That said, PGMs appear vulnerable given valuation- led gains so far and a weaker outlook for earnings and PGM prices. Among Domestics, we think Retailers are likely to perform the best given their higher positive leverage to an underlying consumption recovery and declining rates compared with Banks and Defensives.

Key risks to our positive equity outlook are macro disappointments - particularly disruptions in sustained disinflation that prompt prolonged hawkish SARB policies - as well as domestic political uncertainty, both of which could further restrain domestic growth. Additionally, deeper risks to external growth could also pose challenges given South Africa's high export exposure and sensitivity to global flows.

South Africa's macroeconomic performance in recent years has been lackluster, characterized by sluggish growth and rising debt levels, the combination of which resulted in the country's sovereign credit rating being cut to sub- investment grade in 2017. That said, we argue that growth headwinds are now fading and that fiscal outturns are improving (with public debt likely to stabilize this year and gradually decline thereafter). This suggests an inflection point in South Africa's credit trajectory that bodes more positively for the near- term growth outlook and for a market re- rating of the country's medium- term economic prospects. In our assessment, this outlook is not reflected in the local yield curve (characterized by steepness and high real yields), external debt (where spreads are wide compared with BB- rated peers), or currency and equity valuations (that embed a weaker growth and dimmer sovereign credit rating outlook).

Our core macro view in South Africa in recent years has been that the economy has been operating well below potential, held back by domestic and external headwinds and translating into significant spare capacity and room for a cyclical growth recovery. Put differently, our long- standing estimates of trend growth of around \(2 - 2.5\%\) - arrived at using bottom- up, top- down, and cross- country modeling frameworks - have never been as pessimistic as the official- sector or consensus views that trend growth has fallen to as low as \(1 - 1.5\%\) in recent years. In our assessment, coincident indicators from the labor market and wage and consumer inflation are consistent with this narrative: as growth has slowed to around \(1\%\) in the past decade, the unemployment rate has steadily risen above its longer- run average, wage growth has slowed sharply in real terms, and underlying consumer price pressures have been very subdued.

A number of factors have held back economic growth in recent years. While our analysis places more emphasis on cyclical headwinds than the mainstream view - including tight demand policies, low confidence, and weak external demand - structural factors have also played a role. On this front, supply constraints have visibly eased, with more consistent electricity provision since March 2024 as load- shedding has largely ended, and higher rail and port freight volumes as logistical constraints have become somewhat less severe. Our recent analysis suggests that a major headwind to growth in recent years has been the central bank's restrictive monetary policy stance, on our estimates holding back growth by an annual \(0.5 - 1\) pp in 2023- 24 relative to our estimate of a neutral monetary policy setting. As the interest rate cycle has turned and as low inflation is now supporting real income growth, we see a case for an acceleration in economic growth in the coming quarters. Indeed, our 'beancount' estimate of growth for Q2 suggests upside risks to our standing forecast of \(+0.5\%\) qoq (above the SARB's and consensus forecasts of \(+0.4\%\) qoq). Our baseline expectation is that the recovery in growth that we pencil in over the remainder of this year will be led by the consumer, followed by a more gradual improvement in fixed investment over the medium term. In

our view, the latter will take time as it depends in part on the political backdrop (currently supportive of growth- friendly policies, but somewhat uncertain), as well as greater confidence in the durability of the supply- side improvements underway. Easier financial conditions – as the rate cycle shifts, as the SARB locks in lower inflation over the medium term, and as fiscal metrics gradually improve – would also, in our view, likely support the investment outlook.
Exhibit 1: We expect a domestic demand led growth recovery, driven by consumption
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

The flip side of our more positive view on potential growth vs. the weak recent growth performance is that, in our assessment, a large and disinflationary negative output gap has emerged. This explains the current weak inflation dynamics, as well as the better behavior of core inflation relative to other EM and DM economies during the pandemic period. Our most out- of- consensus view in the past year has been on inflation, with a sharply lower forecast than most, and our forecasts remain low: we expect \(3.3\%\) average inflation in 2026 and a decline to \(3.1\%\) in 2027, below consensus of \(4.1\%\) and \(4.2\%\) (respectively). A large negative output gap also implies room for a strong cyclical recovery that does not erode spare capacity meaningfully or generate inflation, our central scenario. We pencil in an acceleration in growth from \(1.0\%\) in 2025 to \(1.6\%\) in 2026 and to \(2.0\%\) in 2027, with our longer- term GDP growth forecasts at \(2.5\%\) . While our confidence in the timing of the acceleration in growth is relatively low, given global uncertainty as well as still- weak domestic sentiment, our conviction in a medium- term return to \(2\% +\) growth is higher. From this perspective, our forecasts point to a positive inflection point in economic growth relative the past decade of significant weakness.
Despite our bullish medium- term outlook, one reason for caution on the timing of the projected pick- up in growth is South Africa's exposure to the global economy. The

economy is open: exports stand at \(32\%\) of GDP and are up sharply over the past two decades due to terms of trade gains, and commodities make up a larger share than for most peer economies. Thus, South Africa's exposure to the external environment, both via demand and terms of trade (export price) channels, is considerable. Exposure to cross- border financial flows is also meaningful, with significant foreign holdings of South African domestic debt and equities. These flows are sensitive to global risk sentiment, as well as to other macro factors (including the broad Dollar and US rates), factors that explain the Rand's historically high market beta to global factors. As foreigners have incrementally disinvested from South Africa and as local institutional investors have increased their offshore holdings, however, the country's net international portfolio investment position has turned positive, a factor that we argue should ultimately decrease the Rand's global beta over time.

In the near term, external factors for South Africa are mixed, in our assessment. South Africa's two largest trading partners are Europe and China, and our medium- term view on growth in the former is relatively constructive and on the latter is more cautious. Although trade exposure to the US is not that high, the \(30\%\) import tariffs put in place by the Trump administration represent a meaningful headwind to South Africa's automotive sector and to some agricultural exports, even if the overall macro impact of these tariffs is unlikely to be very large. On the positive side, however, terms of trade developments have been supportive: precious metal prices have rallied sharply (up \(50\%\) on a weighted- average basis since end- 2023), with gold prices up \(61\%\) and PGM prices up \(33\%\) over this period. This feeds into exporter margins – precious metal export prices in ZAR terms are at an all- time high – and supports external balances, as well as the fiscal position (through corporate income tax receipts on the back of higher profitability). That said, the read- through from positive terms of trade developments into growth is unclear, given that fiscal windfalls tend to be saved (at least in large part) and that spillovers from higher private sector profitability to either labor or capital are likely limited, i.e., workers are unlikely to see much higher wages and companies are unlikely to increase investment on the back of temporarily higher export prices.

The constructive growth outlook we expect is not yet reflected in South African equities, despite a strong performance at the index level this year. After a range- bound performance for most of the last three years, South African equities broke out of their trading range in 2025, with MSCI South Africa rallying nearly \(30\%\) in local currency and \(40\%\) in USD terms, and outperforming the broader MSCI EM index \((+18\%)\) ytd).

However, at the sector level the performance has been concentrated in a few pockets. Commodity Exporters (which largely include gold and PGM miners) are up around \(100\%\) ytd, and Naspers (which has a \(17\%\) index weight) has rallied \(40\%\) . Together, these two contribute nearly \(90\%\) of the ytd gains. That said, the rest of the domestic market – Financials and Domestic Cyclicals – have been largely flat ytd and trading inexpensive relative to their historical range, suggesting domestic equities are yet to price in any economic acceleration.
Exhibit 2: South African equities broke out of their past 3-year trading range this year and have posted strong gains (nearly \(30\%\) in 2025...
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 3: ...outperforming the broader MSCI EM index YTD
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 4: South African Miners and Naspers have posted strong gains ytd, while the rest of the domestic market - Financials and Domestic Cyclicals - has been largely flat
Exhibit 5: Miners and Naspers have together contributed 90% of the ytd gains (24pp out of 27pp)
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Source: FactSet, Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 6: Domestic sector valuations are trading inexpensive relative to their historical range
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

While the equity market rally has so far been concentrated in Exporters, we think a recovery in economic growth should drive rotation towards domestic parts of the market, notably in Banks and Domestic Cyclicals. Within Exporters, we think the rally in Gold Miners could extend, while PGMs appear vulnerable given micro fundamentals and our baseline commodity views, as detailed below.

Domestic Cyclicals positively geared to local growth recovery and attractively priced As expected, domestic pockets of the South African equity market (which include Cyclicals such as Banks, Retailers and Industrials, as well as Defensive sectors such as Telcos and Consumer Staples) are positively geared towards the domestic growth cycle. Given the strong outperformance of Commodity Exporters, Domestics have lagged broad Exporters by nearly 60pp ytd on a market cap- weighted basis. Consequently, the relative entry point on Domestic stocks looks attractive. We think a pick- up in local growth could trigger a rotation from Exporters (with strong ytd gains) towards laggard Domestic Cyclicals.
Exhibit 7: Domestic sectors in South Africa are positively geared to a cyclical recovery
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 9: The rally in Exporters has been driven by Commodity Exporters
Exhibit 8: Relative entry point for Domestic vs. Export sectors is currently at muti-year lows
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Within the Exporters, the rally has been largely concentrated in the Gold and PGM (Platinum Group Metals) Miners, which has come along with a rally in precious metal prices (gold and platinum).

We note that, for the Gold Miners, the ytd rally has been in line with the historical beta of mining stocks to gold prices. Moreover, the rally in mining stocks is also largely in line with 2025 EPS revisions since the start of last year, suggesting the rally has been backed by underlying earnings accruals (i.e., fundamentals). On the other hand, PGMs have performed better than implied by their historical beta to platinum prices and the sharp rally in stocks has come against 2025 EPS estimates being halved since the start of last year.

Looking forward, our commodity team remains constructive on Gold prices on stronger- than- expected central bank demand and technicals, and expect London spot prices for Gold to reach \(\) 3,700/\(toz by end - 2025 and\) \ \(4,000/\) toz by mid- 2026. On the other hand, they think a sustained rally in platinum is unlikely and expect the spot platinum price to fall back in the range of \(\) 800-\ \(1,150/\) toz from current levels of above \(\) 1,300/\(toz, given the decline in price - sensitive Chinese demand, downside pressure on auto demand from EVs and higher global supply. We thus think the rally in Gold Miners can extend given the positive outlook for Gold and underlying earnings support, while PGMs could be vulnerable to a correction given the weaker outlook for earnings and PGM prices.
Exhibit 10: Within Exporters, Gold and PGM Miners have seen a strong rally this year...
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 11: ...along with a rally in precious metal prices
\\*The PGM basket price refers to the weighted average price of the four primary PGMs in South Africa: \(60\%\) platinum, \(30\%\) palladium, \(3\%\) gold, \(7\%\) rhodium.
Source: Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 12: The price appreciation in South African Gold Miners has been in line with 2025 EPS revisions since the start of last year, suggesting the rally has been backed by underlying earnings accruals...

Exhibit 12: The price appreciation in South African Gold Miners has been in line with 2025 EPS revisions since the start of last year, suggesting the rally has been backed by underlying earnings accruals...
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 13: ...while the sharp rally in PGMs has come along with 2025 EPS cuts
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 14: The rally in Gold Miners has been below the historical beta to spot Gold prices, while PGMs have performed better than implied by their historical betas
Source: Bloomberg, FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Looking at South African Exporters based on their revenue exposure by region, we note that US goods exporters (consumer sectors) have performed well this year \((+30\%)\) ytd on average) and have looked through the tariffs risks, similar to US exporters in the broader EM. On the other hand, China- sensitive exporters (which largely include base metal miners) have remained under pressure given weak manufacturing and property- related demand in China. We think China metal exporters could remain under pressure, as we expect softening trends in China's property market to extend.
Exhibit 15: US exporters in South Africa have looked through tariffs risks and performed strongly ytd, while China base metal exporters have remained under pressure
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Two major policy adjustments are underway in South Africa, both of which should have a bearing on the local yield curve and on country risk premia embedded in macro assets. First, the central bank has announced a reduction in its effective inflation target from \(4.5\%\) to \(3\%\) (from the mid- point to the lower bound of its \(3 - 6\%\) inflation target range). Second, after a decade of fiscal slippage post- GFC, the fiscal authorities are now running primary surpluses that should stabilize and ultimately reduce public debt, enabling them to restore fiscal credibility.

The SARB aims to achieve sustained disinflation at \(3\%\) in the medium term, following years of running a restrictive policy and the recent announcement of a shift lower in its effective target from \(4.5\%\) to \(3\%\) . Our top- down modeling of inflation suggests that most of the hard work towards achieving \(3\%\) inflation on a sustained basis has already been done: underlying (core) inflation is already at \(3\%\) , demand factors are weak, and inflation expectations are declining. The latter have not yet declined to the newly announced lower target, but our analysis suggests strong anchoring properties of inflation expectations to the SARB's inflation target that should imply rapid decreases of inflation expectations in upcoming readings. In our view, this is the most important indicator and determinant of the near- term policy rate outlook, much more so than incoming monthly price data.

Given our view that most of the price of achieving low inflation has already been paid and that expectations should decline sharply in upcoming readings, our inflation outlook is sharply below consensus, at \(3.3\%\) in 2026 and \(3.1\%\) in 2027 (relative to consensus of \(4.1\%\) and \(4.2\%\) , respectively). With these forecasts, we think that the SARB should have space to continue easing policy in the near term, and bring policy rates to a lower terminal rate in the medium term. We pencil in 25bp cuts at the two remaining MPC meetings of the year and cuts at alternating meetings thereafter down to a \(5.0\%\) terminal rate, well below current market pricing of \(6.7\%\) .
Exhibit 16: Our inflation forecast remains below consensus
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

National Treasury (NT) has run small primary surpluses in the last two fiscal years and targets a main budget primary surplus of \(0.8\%\) of GDP in the current year, dynamics that should be sufficient to stabilize public debt this year and reduce it thereafter. In contrast to the authorities' fiscal projections, however, the market consensus is for ongoing fiscal slippage, a view that is shared by rating agencies and the IMF. This implies a significant fiscal credibility gap, reflected in the steepness and high real yields at the long end of the local bond curve. Our view is that NT's projections are credible and that risks are tilted toward outperformance rather than underperformance, the broad pattern in recent years, and in our view consistent with the most recent budget execution data that shed a positive light on the outlook for corporate tax receipts.

If the market were to price in our views on inflation and rates, this would translate into a flattening of the yield curve, out to the belly of the curve. Lower inflation should also reduce the longer end of the curve commensurately, implying a 150bp reduction in the long end relative to the previous \(4.5\%\) target, all else equal.

Meanwhile, if the market prices in the fiscal improvements that we anticipate, we see scope for a reduction in fiscal risk premia at the longer end of the curve. Put together, this implies potential for a significant bull- flattening of the yield curve, as we argued recently.
These dovish policy shifts should bode well for the equity market as South African equities are among the most rate- sensitive within EM. South Africa's equity correlation

with local rates (both the short and long end) has been consistently negative over the past decade (i.e., lower rates have supported higher equity multiples/prices). Moreover, in a weak Dollar environment, South African equities are among the most sensitive EM markets to lower local rates and a weaker USD.
Exhibit 17: South Africa's equity correlation with local rates has been consistently negative over the past decade
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 18: South African equity market stands out as among the most sensitive to lower local rates and a weak US Dollar
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

To gauge the sensitivity of various pockets of the market to lower rates, we look at two sets of separate analyses. First, we calculate the beta of various South African market slices to 5- year ZAR rates (the mid- point of short/long- end rates), controlling for global equity risk appetite (proxied by the MSCI ACWI global equity index). This shows that Domestic Cyclicals, such as Banks and Retailers, have a higher beta to lower rates than other pockets, such as Defensives and Commodity Exporters. Domestic Cyclicals are also trading at relatively inexpensive valuations (vs. their history), suggesting attractive risk- reward going forward.
Exhibit 19: Within the various pockets in South Africa, Domestic Cyclicals (Banks, Retailers) are most positively levered to lower rates and trade at inexpensive valuations
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Second, we run an episodic analysis looking at post- GFC periods when nominal 5- year rates in South Africa declined significantly \((>100bp\) over next 12 months or less). Historically, there have been six such episodes (excluding the recent period of declining rates underway since last year). The broader market has rallied in every single period and posted \(13\%\) median returns in local currency. Within various pockets, Domestic Cyclicals, for example Retailers, have posted the strongest median returns \((+27\%)\) followed by Banks \((+15\%)\) - both outperforming the broader index and other pockets, such as Defensives and Exporters.

Exhibit 20: South African equities have posted \(13\%\) median returns in past periods of declining rates, with Retailers and Banks outperforming other pockets, such as Defensives and Exporters on a median basis
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We think the backdrop of improving domestic growth accompanied by lower local rates should be supportive for South African equities, particularly the domestic pockets. Over the past 15 years (post GFC), the average quarterly performance of South African domestic equities (MXZA ex- Exporters) has been best when local economic growth was improving, and local 10- year yields were falling. In contrast, the worst average quarterly

performance has come when economic growth was slowing, and yields were rising. Our macro baseline view of growth improving towards our estimate of trend economic growth and room for rates to fall thus bodes well for the domestic slice of the market.
Exhibit 21: Domestic equities in South Africa have historically performed best when growth was improving accompanied by lower local rates
South Africa domestic equities: MXZA ex-exporters (Qtrly. Returns since 2010)Growth: GS South Africa CAIRates: ZAR 10Y yieldsFallingRisingAllAccelerating2.7%0.3%Decelerating2.6%-0.4%All2.6%-0.1%
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We think fiscal improvements could also bode well for the broader equity market via a potentially declining country risk premium. Despite lower rates, Banks should benefit as well, as the likely improvement in loan growth and decrease in the cost of risk should more than offset potentially lower NIMs as interest rates fall. Additionally, South African Banks have historically fared poorly on profitability compared with their EM peers given macro concerns around South Africa's high fiscal deficit and debt levels. Consequently, the relative ROEs for South African Banks (vs. EM Bank ROEs) have historically mirrored the relative fiscal deficit trajectories. On a P/B vs. ROE metric, South African Banks are currently trading in line with their EM peers. An improving fiscal trajectory could thus prove supportive for South African Banks' profitability, drive higher valuations and sustain dividend payouts over time.

Exhibit 22: Historically, relative ROEs for South African Banks have remained under pressure given macro/fiscal concerns and mirrored the relative fiscal deficit trajectories; Better fiscal performance is likely to be supportive for Banking stocks
Source: FactSet, Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 23: South African Banks are currently trading in line with their major EM peers on a P/B vs. ROE metric
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

As noted earlier, we think markets are not pricing in our constructive growth and dovish inflation and rates view, offering opportunities across asset classes. We see potential for a bull- flattening of the yield curve and stronger currencies and equities. For equities, in particular, we highlight various index- and sector- level alpha opportunities below.

Despite near- term consolidation risk after strong gains for EM equities broadly, we remain constructive on EM equities over the medium term given relatively firm EM fundamentals, dovish Fed repricing, an improving flow picture and further scope for rotation and diversification within EM. Within EM, we raise South Africa to Overweight and think South African equities could extend their outperformance led by the domestic sector given the expected cyclical growth recovery, mid- teen earnings growth next year, dovish policy, still inexpensive valuations and light positioning. We expect earnings in South Africa to grow \(15\% /8\%\) in 2026/27 (vs. consensus estimates of \(16\%\) and \(5\%\) respectively). Our refreshed 12- month target (end- August 2026) for JSE 40 index is 106,000, which implies \(12\%\) upside in local currency and about \(17\%\) USD returns.

With equity valuations and positioning still conservative, the main risks to our positive equity outlook are macro disappointments - particularly disruptions in sustained disinflation that prompt prolonged hawkish SARB policies - as well as domestic political uncertainty, both of which could further restrain domestic growth. Additionally, deeper risks to external growth could also pose challenges given South Africa's high export exposure and sensitivity to global flows.
Exhibit 24: Investor positioning has declined in South African equities over the past year, with EM active funds currently underweight
Source: EPFR, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
We focus on various thematic alpha ideas below:

1) MSCI South Africa (MXZA) vs. MSCI CEE-3 (MXME). Within the broader CEEMEA region, we think market leadership could rotate from the EM European markets to South Africa. CEE-3 markets have been the outperformers this year (MXME > +50% ytd) fueled by optimism around sustained shifts in Europe's fiscal policy and around European growth. We think these markets could be vulnerable to a reversal. For example, Poland (which accounts for 70% of the MXME index) could see profit-taking given news around potential corporate taxes hikes on Banks and an already less favourable risk-reward due to the negative impact from rate cuts on Banks' earnings and extended investor positioning, moderating earnings momentum and an already overvalued currency. The relative entry point for MXZA vs. MXME looks attractive, with around 20% potential upside to 4Q24 highs.
Exhibit 25: South Africa (MXZA) vs. CEE-3 (MXME) offers attractive entry point, with relative performance about \(20\%\) below 4024 highs
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

2) Domestic vs Exporters rotation. As mentioned earlier, we think a cyclical growth recovery and high sensitivity to lower rates could trigger a rotation into Domestic sectors that have significantly lagged (Commodity) Exporters this year. The relative performance between Domestics and export-related sectors is near two-year lows. While valuations for Domestic sectors are higher than for Exporters in absolute terms, Domestic Cyclicals are trading 0.4 s.d. below the 5-year mean, compared with +1.2 s.d for Commodity Exporters.
Exhibit 26: Cyclical growth recovery and high sensitivity to lower rates could trigger rotation into Domestic sectors that have significantly lagged (Commodity) Exporters this year
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 27: Domestic sector valuations are trading inexpensive relative to their historical range
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

3) Interest rate beneficiaries. Thematically, stocks that are most positively geared to lower rates should outperform as rates decline over the next year. The equal-weighted group of 15 stocks that exhibit the highest and above the market median correlations with 5-year local rates have traded in line with interest rate trends (inversely) in recent years. These stocks have gained about 5% since the SARB announced its new inflation
target in May, while 5- year rates declined by around 50bp. We expect these stocks to perform strongly in a lower rate environment.
Exhibit 28: Our rate-beneficiary stock screen has moved closely with interest rate trends (inversely) in recent years, and gained about \(5\%\) since SARB announced its new inflation target in May
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

4) Intra-sector opportunities: Retailers to lead; Gold Miners vs. PGMs. For investors looking for intra-sector opportunities, we think Retailers should perform the best among the Domestic sectors. Historically, Retailers have outperformed in periods of declining rates and have higher leverage to an underlying consumption recovery than Banks and Defensives. Moreover, although Banks should benefit from stronger loan growth and a lower cost of risk, they could see some offsets from margin pressure with lower rates. Within Exporters, the rally in Gold Miners has been backed by underlying earnings accrual and could extend given our positive outlook for gold prices. On the other hand, PGMs appear vulnerable given valuation-led gains so far and a weaker outlook for earnings and PGM prices.
Exhibit 29: Rally in Gold Miners could extend, while PGMs appear vulnerable
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
The economics content was authored by our South Africa economist, Andrew Matheny.
Exhibit 30: We remain below consensus on inflation and rates in South Africa

Light blue cells indicate GS forecast above Bloomberg (median) consensus, grey cells indicate GS forecast below Bloomberg (median) consensus. For GDP and inflation, annual average data are used for GS forecasts and consensus. For India, GDP and inflation data are referred to fiscal year (2025 is India FY2025). For policy rates, end of year data are used for GS forecasts and consensus.

We, Sunil Koul, Andrew Matheny, Mambuna Njie, Kamakshya Trivedi, Tadas Gedminas and Tarun Lalwani, CFA, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views, which have not been influenced by considerations of the firm's business or client relationships.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Other than certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgment.

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators.
